text: Freud said, “Love and work, work and love. That’s all there is.” Well, I’m retired and my wife is dead. And on that, we ARRIVE on BEN WHITTAKER. Ben just turned Seventy, an Everyman in many ways, but a unique man to al who know him. He exhales as he turns in sync with the oth

-- As you can imagine, that has given me some time on my hands. INT. BEN’S HOUSE - BROOKLYN - NIGHT BEN, wearing a suit and tie, sits in an upright chair in comfortable brownstone, TALKING TO CAMERA. Looks like he’ on VIDEO.

My wife’s been gone for three-and-a- half years. I miss her in every way. And retirement -- that is an ongoing, relentless effort in creativity. At first, I admit, I enjoyed the novelty of it. Sort of felt like I was playing hooky.

A jumbo jet lifts off. BEN V.O. I used all the miles I had saved and traveled the globe.  INT. BEN’S BROWNSTONE - BROOKLYN - NIGHT Ben ENTERS in an overcoat, carrying his suitcase and wear a purple lei around his neck. He stands for a moment in h quiet, empty house. BEN V.O. Problem was, no matter where I went, as soon as I got home, the nowhere to be thing hit me like a ton of bricks.
It’s noisy. Ben walks among the crowd, paper under his ar BEN V.O. I realized the key to this whole deal was to keep moving. Get up, get out of the house and go somewhere. Anywhere.

Crowded with folks on their way to work. Ben sits on a st at a corner table with a bagel and the morning’s Post. BEN V.O. Come rain or shine, I’m at my Starbucks by 7:15. Can’t explain it, but it makes me feel part of something. Two Male Execs in their 40's, ask Ben if they can share h table. Ben’s delighted, moves his papers. The Guys take t two remaining stools, turn them away from Ben and begin a impromptu meeting -- as if Ben wasn’t even there. INT. BEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT Ben to CAMERA.
How do I spend the rest of my days? You name it. Golf, movies, books, pinochle, tried yoga, learned to cook, bought some plants, took classes in Mandarin. (SPEAKS MANDARIN)
Translation? Believe me, I’ve tried everything.

Ben walks the center aisle between the pews. Many of his friends sit around him. He pats a back or two as he looks for an empty seat. BEN V.O. And then of course, there are the funerals. So many more than I could imagine. As Ben looks for a seat, a cute number about Ben’s age, P POMERANTZ, smiles at him, hoping he’1ll sit next to her. then, Ben spots his friend, MILES, who shows him he saved a seat. Ben smiles back at Patty but joins Miles, who sha his head at their deceased friend, lying before them. Ben looks at his friend, tears quickly welling in his eyes.
On Ben’s BED. Ben places TWO GIFTS wrapped in Toy Store wrapping paper on top of his clothes, zips his bag shut.
The only traveling I do these days is out to San Diego to visit my son and his family.

The ceiling is filled with stars that glisten in the dark CAMERA TILTS DOWN past them. BEN V.O. They’re all so great, I love ‘em to pieces, but to be honest, I think I’ve probably relied on them way more than I should. We arrive on a LITTLE GIRL ASLEEP in the top bunk of a bu bed. As CAMERA CONTINUES TO BOOM DOWN we find Ben wide aw in the bottom bunk under Dora the Explorer sheets.

Don’t get me wrong. I’m not an unhappy person. Quite the contrary. I just know there’s a hole in my life and I need to fill it. Ben TURNS TOWARD CAMERA, turns out a small lamp and the SCREEN goes BLACK.
Soon.
Ben EXITS carrying groceries, just about passing by the market’s colorful Bulletin Board.

Which brings me to this morning, when I was leaving Trader Joe's and caught your flyer out of the corner of my eye. CAMERA WHIPS to a flyer -- SENIOR INTERNSHIP PROGRAM AT CLOTHESTHATFIT.coM. OVER Ben’s V.O. reads: SENIORS- BEAN WE NEED YOUR EXPERIENCE AND WE’LL TEACH YOU WHAT WE KNOW! Topay! ON BEN. Amused and intrigued. As he reaches for the flyer

I thought that was you! Ben turns to find Patty, the woman from the Funeral. PATTY (cont'd) What’d you find? (reads for herself) Senior Internship Program at... How do you pronounce this? I hate when they don’t put spaces between the words.
ClothesThatFit.com. I think an internet place is looking for Senior Interns. Am I reading that right?
Lemme see. (skims the Flyer) You have to be over 65, have organizational skills, genuine interest in e-commerce, whatever that is, and a roll up your sleeves attitude. Well, that’s you to aT, kid.
ClothesThatFit... Is that the outfit that took over the--
Yeah, I think they bought one of the factories on Front Street. My daughter tells me they sell clothes on the web. How that works, I have no idea.  Ben tears off the Flyer, then seems thrown.

Oh. You have to upload the application. That could be challenging. Listen to this. (reads ) Cover letters are so old fashioned. (they both react, Ben continues reading) So show us who you are with a cover letter video. (Patty’s confused, Ben reads) Upload your video to youtube or vimeo using .mov, .avi or an .mpg file. We look forward to meeting you. (amused) Okay. I guess that’s meeting me.

I swear, I don’t even know what language that was. What are you doin’ tonight Ben? (peeks in his grocery bag) Frozen Lasagne... I could make a little salad and turn that into dinner for two. (confidentially) Like we did that time but never did again. That was five months ago, you know.
(sweetly) Was it? Yeah, no, we should do that again for sure but okay by you if I take a rain check?
You’re cute you know that?
No, I didn’t... Ben bends down to kiss Patty on the cheek. She takes his and kisses him on the lips.

Don’t wait too long, doll. We're not gettin’ any younger. INT. BEN’S KITCHEN - THAT NIGHT Ben washes his dinner plate, puts it in the empty dish ra Then washes a single glass, puts that in the dish rack.  1 A.M. - BEN CAN’T SLEEP He stares at the ceiling, then impulsively tosses off the covers. A MOTORIZED TIE RACK SWINGS into action. Ben decisively selects a tie. IN THE BATHROOM, now wearing a crisp suit and tie, Ben co his hair. Looks at himself, knows what he has to do.
So -- here I am...
An old model Camcorder is perched on a table, it’s red RE light ON. CAMERA circles behind the Camcorder until it fi what it’s shooting -- BEN, in his suit and tie.

-- applying to be one of your interns because the more I think about this idea, the more tremendous I think it is. I have a ton of knowledge I can share. Love the idea of having a place I can go every day. I want the connection, the excitement, I want to be challenged and I guess I might even want to be needed. The tech stuff might take a bit to figure out, I had to call my nine year old grandson just to find out what a USB connector was...but I’1l get there. Eager to learn. Also, want you to know, I’ve been a company man all my life. I’m loyal, I’m trustworthy and I’m good ina crisis. I read once, musicians don't retire. They stop when there’s no more music in them. Well, I still have music in me. Absolutely positive about that.

A former factory retrofitted as an enormous bullpen. It’s football field of cubicles buzzing like a trading floor. Some have described it as organized chaos -- it’s a young company growing at hyper-speed. The surroundings are not fancy but there’s a coolness factor here that can’t be denied. It’s a start up that’s taken off. Everyone working here is either young or really young. C fashion-y women and sweatshirt-clad engineers. CAMERA quickly moves past cubicles, ENTERING the very swa CUSTOMER SERVICE area, where 25 Young Men and Women wear headsets and chat to their Customers. As we pass by, we H "Good news, I found a size 8 in navy!" “You're right, it should have arrived by now, let me track that for you.” “ these pants are awesome if you have hips. Super slimming. “Yes, we are called ClothesThatFit and I'm very sorry the dress didn't fit... Sir."

We arrive at the last cubicle where JULES OSTIN is mid-ca Jules has been “leaning in” since pre-school -- hard-wire be something, to do something. She prides herself in not wanting to be stereotyped. Her strongest attribute is her very big brain, which unfortunately for those around her, never shuts down. Ever.

(into headset) Okay, let me just review this with you. You have six bridesmaids and you bought six of the silk chiffon Antoinette dresses, in pink. The wedding is in three days and the dresses arrived this morning -- all in charcoal gray. (a co-worker overhears, mouth agape) -- which we don’t even sell, so that’s a bit of a mystery. Rachel, please don’t cry, you have to look fresh for your wedding. Really, let me cry ‘cause this is entirely our fault. So, okay, here’s what we're going to do. I’m going to call the vendor and get this fixed today, I will personally see the dresses myself before they are Fed Exed and they will be at your front door by 10 a.m. on Friday. Let me give you my cell just in case... Ready? 917-582-4848. (Others around her take note of this) Okay? --Well, you’re starting to sound a little better already. Thank you so much for your patience. Oh! I’m also going to refund you back 50% on each dress. It’s the least we can do. No -- thank you! So check this one off your list, this is done! And Rachel, have a great wedding! (hangs up) OhmyGod, how did that happen? Jules looks up and sees her perennially overwrought YOUN ASSISTANT, BECKY -- just out of college and a little nerv around Jules. Becky is an incredibly hard worker but unfortunately has no ability to prioritize or organize. JULES (cont'd) (rises ) I know, I’m late for something.
Yeah. Everything.

But you see why I take customer service calls? This is so good. Learn so much. What’s up? What’s going on? As Becky reads from a Post-It, Jules climbs onto a nearby bike, starts to peddle through the office. Becky tries to keep up, talks fast.

Okay. Candice was waiting for you but had another meeting, she said she'll be back at Two. Your 11:00 is in the conference room, so is your 11:10, finance needs you and I guess you e-mailed a bunch of people at 4 a.m. about something?
-- Oh, good! I forgot about that. I want to figure out a way for girlfriends to shop together on line...make it less of an alone thing. E-mail me that idea, will ya?
Yeah, I like that. (writing quickly, takes out Phone) Is now a good time to call your Mother back?

(What? ) Dude, I’m on a bike... A small Group sings Happy Birthday to a co-worker. They h Jules will stop by but she just waves instead as she peda past. Jules passes by an EMPTY CUBICLE which everyone uses to s their crap. It’s filled with files, shoe boxes, hangers, computer cords. An eye sore. Jules squints at the mess as she rides by.

Near the FRONT OF THE ROOM. On her desk is a ridiculous stack of work, a computer with two monitors, a laptop and sign that says “FOCUS”. JULES (cont'd) (without looking up) Becky... (Becky arrives out of breath. ) Can you patch me in. You okay? Becky nods, hits a few keys on her phone, nods to Jules. JULES (cont'd) (picks up her phone, then

I need creative and marketing... and the buying and merchandizing teams for the silk chiffon Antoinette dress. Oh! Also... Just did some Customer Service calls - we got a great review from a customer in Michigan who said (pulls a note out of her pocket, reads) -- opening our box was like giving a gift to herself. Thought that was cool. A WAVE starts across the office, and as it reaches Jules, does a half-assed version and is off to the Conference Ro

A couple of White Leather Sofas, iPads on security cords on a coffee table. Huge CTF photos on the walls. Lady Gag plays in the b.g. Ben, in a suit and tie, takes in his surroundings as he approaches the 21-year-old jeans and tank top wearing Receptionist who’s eating a taco. Behind her, a huge flat screen runs behind-the-scenes footage of a photo shoot.
Hi, I’m Ben Whittaker. I received an e-mail about an interview for the Senior Intern Program. (kind of laughs at the idea)
Hey Ben, how’s it goin’?  10.
It’s goin’ good. Real good. Thank you.

Excellent. Take a seat right around the corner and someone from Talent Acquisition will come get you. Ben thanks her, heads around the corner mumbling, “Talent Acquisition” and sees a dozen older folks waiting for interviews. It looks like a Doctor's waiting room. Ben ta a seat among them.
A long white table and white chairs. Jules and a group of workers stand, crowding around a computer. One of the gir in the group, holds a small dog.

Guys, you have to remember, the home page has to read in a glance. (backs 4 feet away) Also, none of you are over thirty so you need to get back like this to see what this looks like if you're like over 35. (squints) Okay, so I can’t see anything, but if I could see it, what do you want me to read? (reading) Nine girls one shirt or Check out the fit. ROBBY, mid-twenties, jeans, T-shirt.
Both. But I really want you to see the shirt worn by nine different body types.
Okay, then you gotta make me see that. Try making the photo grid bigger and the type smaller. (the Photo grid ENLARGES) Oh! Love that one of them’s pregnant. ZOE - cute, 30, Asian and pregnant.
Thanks.  11.
It would be good if you could put the girl in the red shirt in the middle? It’s a great red. It’s gonna fly outta here.
We really don’t have the time, Jules. I needed you to sign off on this two hours ago.
I know, but can you try? Robby and Zoe exchange a look as a Tech kid works quickly JULES (cont'd) Mia, tell me that thing again. MIA, striped Tee, bold glasses, typing on her laptop.
Forty-six percent of our visitors don’t go past the home page.
Man, we have to fix that. How long do we have them for before they leave?
Seven to nine seconds.
(totally focused on that remark manages to say) Did we order lunch?
(yells) Becky! The Techie spins his laptop around, shows the new Home Pa to Jules.
I love it.
(hits a few keys) And it’s up.
Thank you! (turns to another group at the table) (MORE )
JULES (cont'd) Okay, the Antoinette dress. Major screw up by the vendor.
In a short sundress, Converse, purple braided hair, walks into her SMALL OFFICE.

There’s going to be a couple of interviews today, Ben. We want to make sure both of us find the right fit. Business as usual is not really our motto so hope you have some fun here. Ben nods, takes a seat in a hot pink chair across from Ke who sits cross-legged on a sofa. KEIRA (cont'd) This is the first time we’re hiring Senior interns. Our Team Manager thought it would be an important interface with the community so our Intern questions might not exactly fit your profile, but, we’re gonna go for it anyway, okay?
Fire away.
Okay. Good. Where’d you go to school?
I went to Northwestern.
Hey, my brother went to Northwestern!
Probably not at the same time.
Probably not. He graduated in 2009.
-- Class of ‘65.
Whoa. What was your major? Do you remember?
By a more Senior Exec. SAMANTHA is 25.
And after Northwestern you went on to..?
I went to work for Dex One. Became the Vice President of print publishing.
Okay, and they made..?

Phone books. (Samantha goes a bit blank) I was in charge of overseeing the printing of the physical phone book. I did that for the last 20 years and before that, I was their VP of Sales and Advertising.
Of the phone book thing? (Ben nods) So do they still make phone books? I mean, doesn’t everyone just Google numbers?
-- I believe they do. But before google, it was how you...
No, yeah, I get it.
Sweet faced, wishes he could grow a beard, reads from an iPad.

-- So, 40 years at the phone book company. That’s amazing. Seriously. So, Benjamin, this is one of our more telling questions for all of our Interns, so I want you to think about this one. Take your time -- Where do you see yourself in 10 years?
(amused) When I’m 80?  14.
Sure. Whatever. (checks application in front of him) Wow. Did not realize you were 70. That’s just not a good question for you. Should we just scratch that one and not--?
Your call, Justin.

Thanks. Okay. It’s gone. (then) You look great by the way. And you're clearly more than qualified for the job. You're super over qualified. What can I say -- great video, great interviews -- Ben, you're in it to win it! You got it, man. Congrats. You’re an intern.
Jules is behind her desk, talking to Eli from the Tech Te Several other tech guys stand behind him, all looking wea
So you're saying by speeding up check out....
-- eighty percent of the addresses in the last 24 hours got screwed up.
Oh, God... (Zoe passes by) Zoe, how's that red shirt doing?
Sold out. We just ordered two hundred more.
See if you can cancel that. Just say “Sold Out”. (Zoe looks confused) It’s more exciting.
Jules, the Photo Studio really really needs you.  15.
(rising, then to Eli) Two really’s. I gotta go.
Jules, we need to deal with this.

I know. Okay, just go back to the way it was but then can you do a deep dive on this? We have to eliminate a button. Think One Click at Amazon. We need our version of that. Gotta make it faster. CANDICE COOK, the Number Two person at CTF joins Jules.

I need you for two minutes -- uninterrupted. Candice is the Ying to Jules's Yang. She came to CTF via eBay and to eBay via Harvard. Candice is the accessible, straight-forward, go-to-person for everyone at the compan Jules, washing her hands with Purell, joins Candice. Cand opens her palm and Jules squirts some Purell in as they z zag around desks. CANDICE (cont'd) Remember when we talked a few weeks ago about the Senior Intern Program?
(reading her phone) No...
Seriously? We had a big conversation about it.
We did? Remind me. Seniors in high school or in college?
Seniors in life. Older people.
(looks up) Hold on. What?
I told you I felt we needed to do an outreach program. You seemed to (MORE)
CANDICE (cont'd) be liking the idea so I put it in motion. It’s gonna be great.
Hold please. You’re hiring Senior Citizen interns? What does that even mean?

There’s been a ton of research on this. The results are, without fail, fantastic. Imagine an intern with a lifetime of experience as opposed to someone who has spent the last four years of their life playing beer pong.
Do they eventually want jobs here?
No, they're all retired. They just want the experience. And I want one to work directly with you.
Candice, c’mon. First of all, I’m not great with older people... you know how I am with my parents. Why do I have to have one?
Because you have to set the tone.
Isn't that your job? It’s my job to make it your job. You’re the founder, everyone looks to you. Now, would you prefer a man or a woman? There’s a great 70 year old woman.
That’s like the same age as my mother. That’s too weird.

Fine. There’s a man everyone loves. I saw his video. He seems amazing. They arrive at the PHOTO STUDIO where all the photos for site are taken. Models, racks of clothes, hair dressers a make-up artists swarm about. As Jules joins the commotion  17.
This is not going to work in my opinion, but how long do I have to do it for? Minimum.
(taking off) Six weeks or we’ll be sued.
I know we never talked about this.

Yeah, we did. He starts tomorrow! INT. BEN’S BEDROOM - THAT NIGHT Ben, excited for his first day of work, sits in his pj’s, the side of his bed, setting his alarm. He then sets a ba up alarm on another clock, placing the two clocks next to another. Ben crosses to his dresser and reviews his wardrobe selec for tomorrow. Hanging on the knobs of the dresser are his suit, shirt, tie. Ben opens a new shoe box, digs through tissue, checks to make sure they are both the same size. Satisfied, he heads for bed...
Back in action. Thank God.

VARIOUS ANGLES: Rows of Young Employees at their computer wearing headsets. Huge flat screens flash images of model Young faces - everywhere. We’re seeing all these details THROUGH BEN’S EYES as he TAKES A TOUR of the OFFICES. JASON, tall, off-beat-cute, mid-twenties leads FOUR NEW INTERNS through the massive space. The New Interns are: Ben, DORIS, early 70's, 4'11”, VICTO Black, professorial-looking and a new Young Intern -- DAV in his twenties and thrilled to be here.

-- So, Interns, all of CTF, is on this one floor and that’s because we're all about communication and teamwork. Everyone works in cubes. No one has an office, not even our founder and CEO, Jules Ostin. Who is actually right over there.  18. Jason points across the office to Jules sitting stationar her bike, talking on her iPhone. JASON (cont'd) She loves to ride her bike through the office. That woman does not like to waste time plus she counts it as exercise.
That’s adorable.
(biting his tongue) Yes it is. Ben looks over at Jules just as she notices the Senior Interns and just as quickly turns away from them.
(to Ben) How ya doin’? (extends his hand) I’m Davis.
(shakes his hand) Hey Davis. Ben Whittaker. Exciting place, huh?
Oh my God, they had one opening for a regular age intern -- no offense, and I got it. I’m so psyched.
I’m pretty psyched myself. Some of the Young Employees pass by, checking out our gro

New interns. (the Kids laugh) Hey, gray is the new green. (walking backwards) A few words about Jules. No, wait, I’1ll let her talk for herself. Jason POINTS A REMOTE at A FLAT SCREEN. A VIDEO begins featuring Jules in the CTF offices.
I’m Jules Ostin and I started clothesthatfit in 2011 after I worked for another on-line shopping site and couldn’t help but notice that almost 50% of all dresses and (MORE )

The words languages 19. JULES (cont'd) pants were returned with one common comment. It didn’t fit! I read the words “It didn't fit” in at least 15 different languages. “It didn't fit" pop on the screen in 15 different -- all handwritten. JULES (cont'd) It’s pretty impossible to know from a photo if something’s right for you, especially when the models are all 5’10 and 100 pounds... (A Photo of a tall, slinky model pops up with an X over her) So I started CTF to let women know how something’s really going to fit before you buy it. Buying clothes on-line should be about more than making the return easy -- it should be all about being thrilled with your purchase. A PHOTO of JULES SITTING AT HER KITCHEN TABLE in front of laptop, surrounded by racks of clothes. JULES (cont'd) I started CTF in my kitchen eighteen months ago. It was just me, a model and a photographer, we were all women and we tried on everything we sold. (QUICK PHOTOS of all 3 trying on clothes, then sitting at computers) Then we described the fit to save you the hassle. We see WHAT THEY'VE TYPED: “Got boobs? This dress is for you!” “Snug fit but super-cool!” “This dress fits everyon We all just bought one!” JULES (cont'd) We called it human curation, then we mixed that with technology and four months later we were launched and now we have 250 people working with us here in Brooklyn and we’re still growing!
(to himself) Wow...  20.
(clicks off the video) Okay, a quick who’s who around here.
So, Ben, you gonna wear a suit everyday?
You bet.
Like that confidence. Plus you got the gangsta thing goin’. Very cool.

(continuing the tour) -- These 3 rows are our Marketing Team, they do everything from on- line marketing to Google search engine optimizaton, followed by Creative - they work on how the site looks and feels then our Merchandisers, Copy and Copy Editing...
(to Victor) -- So far, I’ve understood nothing.

And these four rows are our resident rock stars -- (rows of exhausted Geeks) Our Tech Team. They keep us up and running 24/7 ‘cause those are our store hours. And this corner of prime real estate is the illustrious Intern Team. Guys, meet the new Interns. Six or so scruffy, overworked, very young Interns in dope shirts stop what they’re doing and look at the new, well dressed Interns. Neither gets the group they’re about to become part of. Ben shakes hands with the Intern closest him and that begins everyone shaking hands. JASON (cont'd) Okay, very nice. Last thing. Our perks. We have a free lunch every day, an in-house massage therapist and a world class gym one floor below. New interns, grab a desk, check your e-mail, you may find you've been assigned to one particular person or one team or you may just be a floater. It’s (MORE )

JASON (cont'd) all good. And remember, with great power, comes great responsibility and that’s why we love being interns. Davis sits at a desk, takes out his iPhone, an iPad mini, flash drive, opens up his computer Ben finds an empty desk, sits at it and although the atmosphere is foreign, he takes enormous pleasure in once again, sitting behind a desk. Ben opens his well worn briefcase, takes out a new Pen and Pencil set, a small leather-bound pad, a flip phone, a travel clock. LEWIS, a scrawny sleepy-looking Intern with big hair, sit across from Ben -- watching him. Ben takes out his lucky Pocket Calculator, then an Eyegla Case, then another eyeglass case. He slips on his bifocal raises his neck and looks down at the CTF Screen Saver. Ben stares at the keyboard, not sure what to do when he becomes aware he’s being watched. He looks over, sees Lew eyeing him. Lewis decides to help him out by showing him hit the space bar on his key board. BEN follows, hits his space bar. The computer turns on an lot of icons pop up that don’t look familiar. Lewis helps out again by moving his mouse to the Mail Icon, Clicks. B catches on and does the same.
Oh. Got one.
Congratulations. You're internship will be directly with Founder, Jules Ostin. Becky Scott will contact you with a time to meet Jules. Look forward to meeting you! Just as Ben computes this he HEARS:
I’m in the Photo Studio!
Business Analytics. Perfect.
Floater. Love!!! All eyes turn to Ben.
Looks like I’m a personal intern.  22.
Nice. To...?
Jules... Ostin.

(shakes his head, then to himself) Unfortunate. Jason crosses to Ben, leans over, hugs him, goes back to desk. PING. Ben gets another email. Hi Ben. I have secured an appointment for you to meet Jul Ostin today at 3:55 pm. Please be prompt as Jules has another meeting at 4 pm. Thanks! Becky Scott. BEN reacts to that. A five minute meeting. Wow.
(rises) Goin’ to Merchandising.

Beautiful. Davis offers Ben his fist. Ben pounds it. Awkwardly. Ben notices a Young Woman has come to get Doris. Ben glances around the office, no one is idle. He spots Jules in her Conference Room talking to a large group. Ben's eyes go to his CLOCK. It’s 10:02. It’s a long time ‘til 3:55. As CAMERA PULLS UP AND AWAY, we see everyone o the floor is busy while Ben waits patiently to meet the B CLOSE - BECKY - 3:54 P.M. Becky’s desk is overloaded with work, her half eaten lunc still sits on her desk.

(frazzled, into headset) - I’ll try to have her there at five. Oh, wait, I booked her with a Vendor at 4:45. Let me work on this. (takes an Advil, chokes on it) Call you back. (looks up to Ben) Yes? Hello.  23.
Hi. I’m Ben. (doesn’t ring a bell) Whittaker. I have a 3:55 appointment with Miss Ostin.
(scans computer) 3:55? I thought she was meeting with her new intern.
That’s me. (Becky turns to him) How ya doin’?
I’m sorry, but how are you an intern?
It’s a Senior Intern Program. Just started today.
Oh my God. How’s that going to work? (whispers ) How old are you?
Seventy. You?
Twenty four. I know I look older. It’s the job. It ages you, which won't be great in your case. Sorry.
I actually thought you looked younger.
Yeah, right.
Any tips before I go in?

-- Just talk fast, she hates slow talkers. Or maybe that’s just when I talk slow. Just don’t dawdle, in any way. Keep it moving and don’t forget to blink. (Ben reacts. Blink?) She hates when people don’t blink. It weirds her out. It’s 3:57, this (MORE )
BECKY (cont'd) meeting she’s in just ate up 2 of your five-- The Conference Room DOOR OPENS and Ben watches a group ex BECKY (cont'd) You're up! Go!
Jules is typing on her laptop, her hair thrown up in a po tail. Ben arrives in the doorway, waits for her to acknowledge him. She doesn’t.
Hi Jules... I’m Ben. (Jules looks up) Your new “intern”.
I’m glad you also see the humor in this.
Be hard not to. (BLINKS ! )
So, Ben I was going to say what's a nice guy like you doing in a place like this but Candice gave me the drill so can I just be honest with you?
Please.

I’m not going to have a lot for you to do. (Ben’s surprised) That’s the truth. And, you being assigned to me is kind of just for me to, you know, set an example for the rest of the team. If you ask me, I think you’d probably be much better off working in creative or marketing. It’s a little slower pace. Maybe a little easier to grasp. If you requested a transfer, we could make that happen. Okay?
If that’s what you prefer.  25.
You'll be happier, believe me. I’m not so fun to work for.
That’s what I gather. (Jules looks up) But I can get along with anybody and I’m here to learn about your world, be of help where I can so...
-- You're saying you don’t want to be transferred?
Not really, Sir. (mortified) Excuse me. Terribly sorry. (big blink)
(kind of laughs) It’s not like that’s the first time that’s happened. Okay then. Well, looks like you’re stuck with me. (returns to her laptop)
Great. I’m excited. His smile and enthusiasm throws Jules.
I’1l1 e-mail you when I have something for you to do.
Or I could just stop by a few times a day, check in.
I‘ll e-mail you. And don’t think you need to dress up, we’re super informal here.
I’m comfortable in a suit, so if it’s okay.
No, sure, it’s fine. Old school.
Exactly. At least I’1ll stand out.  26.
I don’t think you'll need a suit to do that.
True. Well, I think we did it in under two minutes. I’1l wait to hear from you. (crosses to the door) Would you like the door open or closed?
Doesn’t matter. Ben exits, CLOSING the door behind him. JULES (cont'd) Open. Actually. Ben opens it back up, slips a last look at Jules. JULES (CONT'D) (cont’d) You'll get used to me.

Look forward to it. INT. BEN'’S BATHROOM - THAT NIGHT Ben, in his pj’s, stands in front of the mirror and dumps all the pills in the “Monday” compartment of his 7 Day Pi Organizer. He catches his reflection and practices blinki
Ben sits at his desk, reading The Times. Everyone around is crazy-busy. The tech-talk is so intense, Ben literally can’t understand a word of it. Jason passes, speed typing his phone.
Ben! You good?
(gives OK sign) Perf. Jason laughs. Ben checks his e-mail. Doesn’t have any.  27.
Ben is trying to figure out where to put his money in the friendly interactive vending machine. A Young Guy comes along, taps on the panel, takes out an apple.
It’s free. Ben tries touching the screen. Nothing happens. Tries aga

Ben is at his computer, getting familiar with the CTF sit He looks over his bifocals and sees the ELEVATOR DOORS CLOSING with Jules inside. He rolls his chair back, looks out the window and sees A DRIVER standing next to an SUV, stomp out a cigarette. Jules EXITS THE BUILDING and heads toward the car. SEVEN P.M. The office is emptying for the night. Davis, slips on his jacket, heading out.
You're staying?
(indicates Jules at her desk) Can’t leave before the boss leaves, Davis. Davis gives Ben a gangsta handshake that Ben stumbles through.

We'll work on that. Ben clicks on his e-mail one last time. Still nothing. INT. BEN’S HOUSE - THE NEXT A.M. Ben’s TWO ALARM CLOCKS go off within a second of one anot We find Ben sitting in a chair, fully dressed, ready to g
(rises) Let's make it happen!

Kiko, the one Young Female Intern, PULLS A HUGE DOLLY sta with reams of printer paper down a row of cubicles. She’s delivering the paper to each desk. Guys in the office sco  28. past her as she lugs the dolly forward, Ben arrives to he pushing the dolly for her. BEN (cont’d) I‘1l push, you deliver.
Thank you!!!

notices Ben pushing the dolly as he and Kiko quickly deli the paper. She also notices Ben is getting smiles and tha from many of the Young Women he passes. LATER - AT DAVIS’ DESK Ben and Davis look at data on Davis’s screen.
Okay, so they want to know what customers bought who didn’t come back - so they can spot the problem, if there is one, right?
Yeah, but I don’t get how to...
-- Alright, here’s how I think we should do this.

(joining them) -- Okay, Ben, here she comes, watch how she won't... (Becky heads in their direction) -- Hey, Beck, what’s up? You look really nice tod-- Becky walks right past, ignoring him. Jason turns to Ben. JASON (CONT'D) (cont’d) How long can a woman be mad at you for?
Kind of depends on what you did.
First of all, nothing on purpose. We were going out for a minute, she was cool...I really liked her... (confidentially) -- then I... like sort of had sex (MORE )

JASON (cont'd) with her roommate. (Ben winces) I had no idea she was her roommate. Met her out. How would I know? Ben notices A STRIKING WOMAN, late fifties or sixty, cros through the office. She has a natural look, soft clothes, soft hair, and a warm comfortable confidence. JASON (CONT'D) (cont’d) Ben, you have a lot of experience, how long will she be mad at me for?
Jay, I have zero experience and I can tell you there’s no coming back from this one.
I assume you’ve talked to her, apologized, told her what she means to you. (Jason stalls...) You didn’t talk to her? What did you do? Send her a tweet?

No. Of course not. I texted her, like a billion times, she didn’t answer, then I e-mailed her, but you know, like a nice e-mail, a long one. (Ben looks at Jason over his bifocals. That’s all it takes) I should probably just actually speak to her. (to himself) Obviously.
Can’t imagine it would hurt. Jason nervously nods, pats Ben on the back. Ben tries to find the Pretty Woman again, but she’s nowhere to be foun

Did yesterday’s numbers come in? Candice looks through a stack of papers she’s holding as Jules washes her hands with Purell. Jules SQUINTS across room SPOTTING BEN pitching with a Young Copy Writer. She types as he talks.  30. JULES (cont'd) My intern sure keeps busy.

Mr. Congeniality. Big hit. Everyone loves him. Jules washes her hands again with Purell. CANDICE (cont'd) You just did that. You're going to wash the skin off your hands. Candice hands Jules a print out as Jules pauses at the cubicle that’s been turned into the community junk pile. so clearly annoys her, and to make things worse, someone drops a case of water on the chair.
Okay? Seriously?
clicks on his e-mail, leans forward - shocked. He actuall has one. Subject -- NEED YOU!
Ben awaits his orders. As always, Becky is on her headset overwhelmed, juggling a zillion things.
(to Ben) -- Jules spilled soy sauce on her Stella McCartney jacket, can you take it to the photo studio, they have all kinds of cleaners and stuff in there.
Sure. Where’s the jacket?
(duh?) She's wearing it! (Ben hesitates) Go in and get it! (into headset) I’m sorry. You need the proofs back by when?  31.
Candice and Jules are clearly in the middle of something important. Leftover sushi sits between them.

Wow. I did not see this coming. But I should have.... They want me to bring in a CEO? Why? Because they think I’m... what? Too inexperienced at running a business... (Candice almost nods) Didn't go to Harvard...? (Candice tries not to nod) My work habits aren’t by the book..? I mean, isn’t that how we got here? Really? I need adult supervision? Jesus, I’m the oldest one in the whole office! How do you feel about this? Tell me the truth.
I think it’s worth exploring.
Why? Could we be doing better? We hit our five year goal in nine months.

Exactly. Jules, we can’t keep up with our own success. You know that. You’re an hour late to every meeting. We have a name for it. Jules Standard Time. And I get it, there’s just so many hours in the day. We’re all playing catch-up. Our tech guys are working ‘til two, three in the morning. Customer Service is swamped. We’re running out of inventory. We have shipping issues, programming problems. And the bigger we get, the more complicated it’s gonna get. And honestly, your time can be better spent than worrying about so much minutia. How much time did we spend last week setting up the L.A. warehouse? And because you were doing that, we never met all week with engineering...
Isn't this what a start up is? (sees Candice is about to say something) (MORE )
JULES (cont'd) -- What? Say it. What’s everyone worried about?

That it’s all going so fast, it can get away from us. The VC’s think a seasoned CEO will take things off your plate -- that’s all -- free you up to do what you do great. You come up with the ideas and let someone else make the trains run on time. (Jules hates this) They’re not only our investors, Jules, they’re our partners -- they do want what’s best for us. They want us to make it.

But Candice, that new person is going to run things their way. Technically be my boss. How can I do what I do and have to report to someone else, run every idea I have by this person? Can you see that working?
Gilt Groupe brought in a CEO, how are they doing?

I know, but, for me this is... I mean get me CEO lessons, but don’t... (her eyes fill up with tears) BEN O.S. -- Excuse me. Candice and Jules turn to see Ben standing in the doorway Jules quickly recovers.
I apologize but Becky said you needed something taken care of...on your jacket...
Oh, right-- Keeping her face turned away, Jules takes off her jacket, slides it down the table, then quickly dabs at her eyes. catches the jacket, pretends not to see her tears.  33.

Thanks Ben. (Ben nods, EXITS) The VC’s made up a list of potential CEO’s. Let’s look at the list, explore it, then decide. Baby steps. Jules struggles with how to respond. BECKY’S DESK Ben passes by with Jules's jacket. Becky stops typing.
Something big going on in there?
I couldn't say.
You were in there a long time.

(touches his left ear) I can’t hear a thing. Becky doesn’t believe him. He doesn’t give. She returns t her typing. Ben spots Jason nearby mouthing: “Say something about me her!!!" Ben gestures he should come over himself. Becky looks up. Ben covers. Becky wonders why Ben is still hanging around. BEN (cont’d) On my way, boss.
As Ben packs up his briefcase, he notices Jules sitting a in the Conference Room. She wipes the corner of her eye, turns her back to the room.
Hey Ben. Ben? (Ben turns) How old’s that briefcase? Ben looks down at his well worn, very loved briefcase.
It’s a 1973 Dunhill London Two Buckle. They don’t make this one anymore.  34.
(eyeing it) I’m a little in love with it.

It’s a classic, Lewis. Unbeatable. Ben turns his attention back to Jules and sees her leavin the conference room, wearing her sunglasses. She heads fo the elevator, clearly in a funk. Ben takes this in, snaps his briefcase shut.

Jules makes her way through the office, still in her sunglasses, carrying her iPad, holding a Starbucks. As sh passes the desk usually piled high with everyone’s crap s stops short. It is now a cleaned up perfectly empty cube. Those around her watch her react.
Okay, this is thrilling. A few people nearby laugh. Jules takes off her sunglasses JULES (cont'd) I swear I was going stay late and do this myself.
Ben came in at 7 this morning and did it.
Who? A few others look up. She doesn’t know him?
Ben. Your intern. Jules cranes her neck to find Ben, doesn’t even know wher look. Candice watches from her desk and hits the P.A.
(over the P.A.) Ben Whittaker! WIDE - A SEA of CUBICLES BEN’S HEAD RISES OUT OF HIS CUBE, wondering what’s up.  35.

(spots him - points to the clean cubicle) Brilliant! Thank you! Best thing that’s happened around here all week. Ben raises two fingers to his forehead, saluting her from across the room. The entire office applauds.

Ben is on-line at his desk when a LOVELY PAIR OF HANDS be massaging his shoulders. WOMAN O.S. This is your gift for a job well done. Ben turns, looks up and there she is -- The beautiful Wom he spotted days ago, across the room. She speaks with an English accent and smells like lavender. She rubs his shoulders.
I’m Fiona -- the house masseuse. This feel okay?
Feels great actually. Thank you.
You're a bit tight, Ben.
Haven't sat at a desk for a while. My body’s not used to it.

I get it, plus they say “sitting” is the new smoking. Let me see what I can do. Ben inhales deeply as she massages him. Feels good. Lewis and Davis smile to one another. Ben’s a happy guy. FIONA (cont'd) I spotted you the other day, in the lunch room. (Ben can’t believe that) Then someone told me you were an intern. So clever of you to do this.  36.
It’s a brave new world. Thought I’d jump in, see what it’s all about.

(pulls up a chair, reaches under Ben’s jacket) Absolutely. I’m constantly amazed at what they do here. Love being part of it. As Fiona slides her hands down Ben’s back and toward his Ben’s eyes go wide. Davis and Lewis sit on either side of Ben. Lewis’s eyes widen, then he indicates Ben’s crotch. Davis checks it ou Whoa. Big Ben. He definitely has an erection. FIONA (cont'd) Feeling better?
(barely able to speak) Much. Davis tosses a newspaper on Ben’s lap.
Here you go. Ben nods appreciatively, nervously spreads out the paper. Fiona straightens out Ben’s jacket, a final rub on the shoulders.
Great to meet you. Love that there’s another oldie but goodie here. (hands him her card) See you again?
Love to. And with a final pat on Ben’s shoulders, she’s off. Ben watches her go, then puts a fist out on either side and b boys pound him.

head_text.subj: BEN, DAVIS AND LEWIS WALKING THRU THE OFFICE

text: The Boys are returning from lunch.
So, wait, you're saying you shave every day of your life -- even on Sundays and even if you know you’re (MORE )
LEWIS (cont'd) not going to see anyone you know... (Ben rolls his eyes)

(reads his iPhone) How is this possible? I’m on cheapapartments.com and I literally can’t afford a single apartment in all of Brooklyn. (scans the site) My parents gave me two weeks to find a place and that is just not going to happen.
Getting evicted?

Hey, I’m in no rush but apparently they are. Something catches Ben’s attention OUT THE WINDOW. He move closer, sees JULES'S DRIVER, tucked in an alley, drinking from a paper bag then stashing the bottle in his pocket. seems to have a slight balance problem when he tries to answer his cell. Ben turns, LOOKS FOR JULES - SEES her slipping on her jac
The Driver, MIKE, stands by the SUV, popping a couple of Chiclets in his mouth. Ben approaches, a bit out of breat
Hey, how’s it goin’? Mike, right?
Yeah.
I’m Ben, I work for Jules.
(not much eye contact) She'll be down in a minute.
I know, look, I don’t want to make you uncomfortable but I just happened to have looked out the window and it appeared you were drinking something from a bag, so --  38.
(heading for the car) I don’t know what you’re talking about Pops.
(sees Jules heading out) Why don’t you tell Jules you can’t drive her today or I’m gonna have to. Jules arrives, sees Mike and Ben.
(to Mike) We all good?

Yeah. Mike opens the rear passenger door, Jules gets in. As Mik about to close the door, he looks up, sees Ben has moved closer. MIKE (cont'd) -- Jules... (She looks up at him) Sorry to do this, but I’m actually not feelin’ so hot -- not sure I should be driving. Wouldn’t want to give you anything.
Oh, sure, yeah. No, take the day off and feel better, okay? Mike thanks Jules and EXITS. Jules immediately washes her hands with Purell, checks her watch.
I’m happy to cover for Mike..
(Jules looks up, sees Ben at the open door, holding the car keys) That's okay, Becky can drive me.
Really? You want to give her more to do?
Ben is now behind the wheel.  39.
(typing on her iPad) Hope you don’t mind if I don’t get in the front. Not trying to be rude but I think better in the back. I mean, I could get in the front but...
(stopping her) -- This is perfect.
(reading her iPad) Yeah. (cell RINGS) And everything you hear in the car is strictly confidential, okay?
Goes without sayin’.
(answers cell) Hi Mom... She places the call on SPEAKERPHONE while typing on her i
I found you!
Yeah... What’s up? How’s everything?
Everything's comin’ along. Your Dad and I are finally putting together all our research at the hospital.
(typing) That great...
I hear you typing... (Jules types more softly) We've been studying women under 40 who sleep less than six hours a night...
(suddenly interested) And? What’d you find out?  40.
Seems they’re approximately 38% more likely to experience major weight gain and 11% more likely to become obese compared with women who slept 7 hours a night.
(looks down at herself) Are you kidding me! You know I haven't slept in two years.
I can’t change the facts, dear.
(typing) a Look, Mom, I’m rushing into the city for a meeting and I need to prepare. Can I call you when I get home?
You don’t have to.
Okay. Love you.
Thank you. Ben can’t help but react to that. Jules looks into the re view mirror. Ben’s eyes are steady on the road. PING. Jules clicks on Face Time on her iPad. It’s Candice
How we doing? Did you look over the material on Sheekey?
I did... CMO Travelocity, Citigroup... I get it. He’s major.

He is. And the best thing about him is he’s been watching us and he loves what we’re doing. But he’s only one of the names on the list, so if you don’t like him, we move on. But try to be open. He’s supposed to be kind of brilliant and the VC’s love him. A lot.  41.
Acchhh. Mark Zuckerberg never brought in a CEO. And he was a teenager. Ben agrees. Tries not to nod. Jules notices.
Call me after!
We’re on PARK AVENUE. Jules steps out of the car.
This shouldn’t take more than an hour, if you can’t stay here, I’‘1l call Becky and she’1l find you, then just pull up and--
--I'll be here.
Oh. (almost to herself) I think I forgot to eat today.
Should I pick you up some sushi?

No, I eat too much mercury. I’1l be fine. I’m good. I’m also kinda nauseous, SO... Jules's eyes go up to the skyscraper in front of her, the looks to Ben, a bit self-conscious. Ben gives her a “go g ‘em” kind of fist-move. She acknowledges it, nods.

Jules follows an Assistant down a long corridor. She’s nervous, her palm hitting the side of her leg, heart pounding. The Assistant shows her into a large office whe ERIC SHEEKEY stands with his back to the door. He hangs u from a call and turns in Jules’s direction. Jules catches Eric’s ready smile and dimples he’s a bit t proud of. They shake hands but all Jules sees is: ERIC’S HAIR. He uses a product that gives him a wet look. strand strategically falls on his forehead.  42.

Jules! Because of Jules’s state of mind, she catches only PIECES what Eric says. JUMP CUTS tell the story. ERIC (cont'd) Congratulations. You are a great merchant and a passionate visionary. (Jules forces a smile) But let’s look at where you are from 30,000 feet, shall we? (Jules is finding it hard to swallow) You’ve had your arms wrapped around the business really well -- until the last two quarters. But what everyone wants is a long term sustainable business and at this point, we still need hyper-growth. So what’s the plan to make that happen for CTF? Jules starts to answer but a cough comes out instead. Eri pours water from a sleek water pitcher and holds the pitc up a little too high, the water flowing in slow mo, right into the glass. We both know 90% of all tech companies fail so you're going to need me, or someone like me to get you over this hump. We also know mobile is the future... you need a plan for that and you needed it six months ago. (hands Jules the glass of water) -- You have relentless perseverance, Jules, I'll give you that, but that’s not enough to get you where you need to be. My role will be to keep my head out of the cyclone, provide insight, direction and stability. I’ve been right here before. (Jules shifts her position) Now I have some great people I'd like to bring over with me -- very smart, very pedigree’d. Different level. (Jules wipes her upper lip - different level???) I guarantee you by next quarter we will do far more than make the trains at CTF run on time. (MORE )

(cont'd) (Jules drinks the water) I’ve watched what you’re doing Jules and it’s exciting. Your obsessive focus on the customer serves you well, I see it in all the data, but the money’s never there until it’s there. So, take the next step, strengthen your infrastructure and make some changes -- and next year at this time, you'll be killing it and right where you should be -- hangin’ with the big boys. That’s a promise. As Eric ends his speech his eyes land on Jules's thigh -- skirt has hiked up a little too far. Jules catches his lo He doesn’t have the decency to look away.
CAMERA rushes to keep up with her. She stops at the curb, her eyes searching when the SUV pulls right up to her.
Jules, safe in the backseat of the car, catches her breat
That was fast.
Not fast enough. Jules Purells her hands, notices a brown bag next to her seat. Opens it.
I picked you up some soup from a place I know.

Thanks, really, you didn’t... (opens the bag) -- Oh, it smells so good. Jules opens the container, dips in the spoon, has some. JULES (cont'd) Highlight of my day. Jules phone RINGS. She hits speaker. JULES (cont'd) Word travels fast.  44.
Pretty short meeting.
Yeah. I hated him. Ben reacts. Ben tries
Really? I heard he’s so wonderful.
He is -- in a loathsome sort of way. not to smile.
What went wrong?

I thought he was a condescending sexist know-it-all who did not seem to get what we do, at all, and honestly, I think he’d run our company in a completely inorganic way that would lose us all the customers we've killed ourselves to get. And I also think he’d replace us as soon as he could. Swear to God. And worst of all -- never blinked. An Olympian non-blinker.
Okay, then.
Yeah... (eats her soup, Candice waits) Did you hear my idea about putting bows on the boxes, based on that gift thing that customer said. That would be good, right?
We have a dozen ribbons on your desk to pick from.
Thanks... (Jules softens) See you in the a.m.?
Be there or be square.  45.
I’m sorry.
Don’t be. Ben nods to himself. He looks in the rear view mirror. Ju leans back, closing her eyes.
The SUV pulls up in front of a beautiful but aging townho This 19th Century facade is lean and white with a tall bl door.
(as she gets out) Thanks for helping out with Mike today and getting me chicken soup -- Oh, and cleaning up that cubicle...that was awesome. Seriously.
You’re very welcome. Ben starts to say something, decides not to. Jules moves the passenger window, peers in.
-- It’s okay. I really won’t bite.
You started this business a year and a half ago by yourself and now you have a staff of 250 people. Remember who did that.
Who? I’m kidding. Thank you.

And I hate to say it but -- try to get some sleep. Jules smiles in a very tired kind of way. Ben watches as Jules climbs the stairs to her front door. The DOOR OPENS and to Ben’s surprise Jules's FAMILY GREETS HER. Newly energized, Jules runs to greet her 4 year old daugh PAIGE. Paige flies into Jules's arms. Ben watches, a bit struck that Jules is a Mom. He had no idea. Behind Paige is Jules's husband, MATT, in jeans, t-shirt, open flannel shirt. Matt has an adorable smile and an immediate feeling of authenticity about him.  46. Jules turns back, waves good night to Ben. Ben waves back BEN (cont’d) (driving off) Over the hump.
The house is partially under construction. Jules carries Paige into:
The only room downstairs that’s been finished. Long open shelves, an island, a farm table. Pots and pans are on th stove. Play-doh spread across the island.
Guess what? Maddie said she didn’t want to be my friend anymore.
Oh, I don’t think she means that, she'd miss you too much. (Paige nods, agreeing)
(hands Jules a glass of wine) I’m convinced Maddie is bipolar. We go through this every other day. How was your meeting? It was today, right?
(sipping the wine) Just had it.
(indicating play-doh) Daddy, can we finish?
Let me talk to Mommy for a sec.
Mommy I think I’m winning, look! Matt and Paige are in a Play-Doh Cake Challenge.
Which one is yours, let me guess. (Paige smiles at Matt) Well, I love the pink one so much --  47.
That’s mine! Are you happy at me?
So happy at you. Beyond happy at you!
Daddy helped me with the icing.
Good job guys. So, what’s for din, it smells so good.
Turkey burgers. But we ate ours.
Sorry. We were starved.
We were. But we’ll sit with you, don’t worry.
Thank you angel. How ‘bout I give you your bath first.
(doing dishes) -- Wait. Tell me, I was waiting for you to call. Did you like the guy or..?
Thought he wasn’t the right fit. For me. Kinda scary actually. (Matt looks disappointed) There’s a lot more names on the list, so... Matt nods as Jules ponders why he’d want this.
Ben takes leftovers out of the fridge. A Django Reinhardt plays while Anderson Cooper is on mute. Ben is clearly feeling upbeat as he playfully hits his Voice Mail on his phone.
Ben! Haven’t seen you in days.
That's right, homey, Ben’s got a job!  48. Next -- Patty, the woman Ben ran into at Trader Joe's.
Oh, you’re never home! What are y-- Never mind! Oh. It’s Patty! (CLICK)
Ben laughs, then digs in his pocket, brings out Fiona’s c He crosses to the phone, thinks for a sec, then dials, quickly pouring himself a drink and taking a sip -- but s answers too quickly.

(swallows fast, then) Fiona, hi. This is Ben Whittaker from -- Oh, good to hear your voice too... (Ben makes a victory fist) INT. PAIGE’S BEDROOM - LATER THAT EVENING Paige is still awake but under the covers. The light is d Next to her, Jules is asleep, with one of Paige’s books o against her chest. Matt steps in the doorway.
(softly) Jules?
Sh-sh... let her sleep, Dad. Matt sees that Jules is out cold then covers his disappointment in front of Paige.

Jules ENTERS and finds Matt asleep. She feels badly she’s missed their evening -- she clicks off Kimmel, crosses to side of the bed, gets under the covers. She lifts her lap top onto her lap, checks her e-mail.
I tried to stay up.

I know. I’m sorry I fell asleep in there. I passed out. (Matt doesn’t answer, could be back asleep) I know we had a plan to have a grown-up conversation tonight. (Matt opens one eye) Do you understand what’s happening in Yemen? I’m kidding... I mean, I (MORE )
JULES (cont'd) don't understand it, but... (Matt shuts his eyes) Want to Netflix something? Silence. Disappointed, she resumes typing.

Sorry. Fell out for a sec. Paige learned to say “humongous” today. Cracks me up. But I think I’m ready for her to start school full time. I hate to sound like the other Moms but I’m feeling I need a little “me” time.

I know... She waits. He doesn’t answer. Seems to be back asleep. He turns on his side, AWAY FROM HER. Jules moves her computer off her lap, sidles up behind Ma kisses his neck. No response. JULES (cont'd) Anybody home?
Can't keep my eyes open, Jule. We'll do it tomorrow, k?
(moving back to her side) How many nights in a row has one of us said that? Matt turns to Jules, takes her hand. She looks at him, hopefully.

Can you turn out your light? Jules turns out her light. The Screen goes BLACK. INT. BEN’S BEDROOM - THE NEXT MORNING - STILL DARK A RINGING PHONE wakes Ben from a dead sleep. On his nightstand, we see the book -- Twitter for Dummies.
Hello.
Hey Ben, it’s Becky. From Jules' office.  50.
(looks at his clock - it’s
Hey, what’s up?
Jules's driver is MIA. He’s not answering any of my texts. I know you drove Jules yesterday and I didn’t hear any complaints, so can you pick her up this morning?
Sure.
You know where she lives?
(is she kidding?) I was there yesterday.
Okay, so you remember?
Yes.
(loudly) And you're hearing me, right? (Ben rolls his eyes) Ben!!!
Loud and clear, boss.
Okay, so be there at 7:45, ring the bell and walk away. She’1ll know it’s you.
Ring bell, walk away. Got it. BEN’S FINGER ON JULES'S DOOR BELL He rings, waits a sec.
-- Oh. Walk away. Just as Ben turns to walk away the door OPENS. Ben turns back, Matt is at the door.  51.
Hi, you’re here for Jules?
Yes, hi. Sorry. I’1l wait in the car.
She’s on the phone... want to come in? Just made some coffee. (Ben hesitates) Could be a while. (offers his hand) I’m Matt.
Ben Whittaker.
Daddy!
Come on in, watch your step. Ben pauses in the ENTRY as he HEARS Jules's Voice upstair
Paige sits at the island, eating Oatmeal and playing a ga on an iPad.
Have a seat, Ben. Paige this is Ben. He works with Mommy. Ben takes a seat on the stool next to Paige. Matt hands B a mug of coffee then starts packing Paige’s lunch box.
(to Paige) Hi...
(showing him her iPad) I'm playing Princess Memory Game.
Looks like you’re about to win.
